field.label: Enable DNSCrypt-Proxy
field.help: This will activate DNSCrypt-Proxy service.

field.label: Listen Address
field.help: Set the IP address and port combinations this service should listen on, e.g 127.0.0.1:5353 and/or [::1]:5353

field.label: Allow Privileged Ports
field.help: This will allow you to run the service on port 53.

field.label: Max Client Connections
field.help: Set the maximum number of simultaneous client connections to accept.

field.label: Use IPv4 Servers
field.help: Let DNSCrypt-Proxy use IPv4 enabled servers.

field.label: Use IPv6 Servers
field.help: Let DNSCrypt-Proxy use IPv6 enabled servers.

field.label: Use DNSCrypt Servers
field.help: Let DNSCrypt-Proxy use servers with DNSCrypt protocol enabled.

field.label: Use DNS-over-HTTPS Servers
field.help: Let DNSCrypt-Proxy use servers with DNS-over-HTTPS protocol enabled.

field.label: Require DNSSEC
field.help: Only use DNS server with DNSSEC enabled.

field.label: Require NoLog
field.help: Only use DNS server without user request logging.

field.label: Require NoFilter
field.help: Only use DNS server without own blacklisting. There are many servers deleting ads or with parental control enabled.

field.label: Force TCP
field.help: Always use TCP to connect to upstream servers. This can be can be useful if you need to route everything through Tor, otherwise keep it disabled.

field.label: Proxy
field.help: Use this to route all TCP connections to a local Tor node, format has to be like 127.0.0.1:9050

field.label: Timeout
field.help: How long a DNS query will wait for a response in milliseconds.

field.label: Keepalive
field.help: Keepalive for HTTP (HTTPS, HTTP/2) queries in seconds.

field.label: Cert Refresh Delay
field.help: Delay in minutes after which certificates are reloaded.

field.label: Ephemeral Keys
field.help: Create a new, unique key for every single DNS query. This may improve privacy but can also have a significant impact on CPU usage.

field.label: TLS Disable Session Tickets
field.help: Disable TLS session tickets - increases privacy but also latency.

field.label: Fallback Resolver
field.help: This is a normal, non-encrypted DNS resolver, that will be only used for one-shot queries when retrieving the initial resolvers list, and only if the system DNS configuration does not work. Format is e.g. 9.9.9.9:53

field.label: Block IPv6
field.help: Immediately respond to IPv6-related queries with an empty response. This makes things faster when there is no IPv6 connectivity.

field.label: Cache
field.help: Enable a DNS cache to reduce latency and outgoing traffic.

field.label: Cache Size
field.help: Set the cache size.

field.label: Cache Min TTL
field.help: Minimum TTL for cached entries.

field.label: Cache Max TTL
field.help: Maximum TTL for cached entries.

field.label: Cache Negative Min TTL
field.help: Minimum TTL for negatively cached entries.

field.label: Cache Negative Max TTL
field.help: Maximum TTL for negatively cached entries.

field.label: Server List
field.help: Set a list of known servers e.g. if you want to stick with Cisco only. You can also put your manually added servers here. Please use on your own risk.

field.label: Enable query logs
field.help: This will enable/disable local logs. This includes both [query_log] and [nx_log] as described in the DNSCrypt-Proxy documentation.

field.label: Disabled Servers List
field.help: Exclude servers from automatic selection. Add any specific server names here if you do not want to use them for any reason.

field.label: Relay List
field.help: Set a list of relays. Will be used for relaying to all configured servers.
